job_description: Headed by the agencyâ€™s General Counsel/Deputy Commissioner for Legal Affairs, the Legal Affairs Division serves as the in-house legal department for the New York City Department of Finance.  The Division provides professional and comprehensive legal advice and services in support of a full range of City tax and other revenue-related matters handled by the Department of Financeâ€™s operating divisions.  Legal Affairs attorneys handle diverse legal areas including New York City real property taxes and exemptions; City business income and excise taxes; collections; parking violations; treasury; land registry;  FOIL; employment law; among other things.    Within Legal Affairs, the Collections Unit supports the agencyâ€™s debt collections efforts, handling the collections of business and excise tax warrants, bankruptcy issues, collections of environmental control board violations and may also collect other debt.  Reporting to the Director of the Collections Unit, the unit seeks an experienced collections attorney to work independently and capably represent the agency in debt collection matters including ECB debt, legal research, review of debt and other legal and collections related documents for collections, negotiation of agreements with debtors, mortgage foreclosure matters, bankruptcy issues and legal process to enforce judgments.     Under direction, with wide latitude for independent judgment and unreviewed action, the selected agency attorney will handle the following:   - Perform legal research and draft memorandum, legal responses and other documents as     needed on complicated, important or high value debt collection matters  - Research and review debt for collections using agency computer systems such as Fairtax,     the statement generator, the data warehouse, CACS and AIMS,  - Work on issues with the new computer systems  - Prepare, review and/or sign legal collection and enforcement documents including     executions and restraining notices as needed.  - Handle mortgage foreclosure matters and submit surplus money claims.  - Handle claims against an estate  - Prepare legal responses to questions from the Collections Division and other agency     operating divisions  - Collect debt, including ECB and tax warrant debt and provide legal services in support of     debt collections efforts.  - Work with the Sheriffâ€™s Department on issuing executions, restraining notices, information     subpoenas and other documents as needed.  -  Review, analyze and draft legislation, policies, regulations and statutes.  - Work with staff in the Collections Division on collections projects and matters.   - Working with the Director and other attorneys as needed, provide legal counsel to the     agencyâ€™s operational staff. Assignment topics may include legal work relating to the CPLR,     collections issues, judgment issues, ECB and other City debt and other areas as needed.  - Handle general legal matters and special assignments including representing the agency in     court and administrative proceedings as needed.   - Research and draft legal responses to claims or actions filed against the agency as needed.

job_description: The Web Manager will direct, develop, and manage HPDâ€™s website to support the strategic mission and goals of the agency and ensure that this primary communications channel is clear and accessible to multiple audiences.  The web manager will be responsible for writing, editing, and proofreading website content; keeping program and department pages updated; and developing a clear and consistent voice for all aspects of the agencyâ€™s online presence. Working closely with other departments, the web manager will assess digital content needs across the agency and create and/or edit compelling and sustainable content for the website and other digital projects.  In addition, he or she will coordinate print and online publication schedules across departments, and assist in the conceptualization, design, and execution of email newsletters and online marketing and outreach campaigns. This person will also work closely with the technical team in HPD and at DOITT to enhance the site infrastructure and design, and maintain site standards with regard to new development.   Key Responsibilities:   Manage the strategic direction for HPDâ€™s web site and oversee the content, design, conceptual framework, and site infrastructure; recommend and implement changes to site structure and functionality; ensure communications channel adheres to the goals and objectives of the agency.   Create, edit, and manage content for the agencyâ€™s website and work with other departments across the agency to plan and create fresh and timely content; ensure accuracy, relevance, and consistency of data; and optimize the user experience.   Oversee web updates including template art, logo usage, and overall design to support agency goals and objectives and to maximize synergy with other digital and print materials, and ensure adherence to City styles, standards, and practices.   Work with the new media director and other members of the communications team to plan, develop, and implement a variety of projects in support of the agency's online presence: web sites, blogs, video and multimedia projects, social media sites, and mobile sites and apps.  Maintain a consistent look and feel across the website that carries into other digital projects and print materials; coordinate print and online publication schedules across departments.   Working with a cross-departmental team, maintain and develop the master content calendar for all web pages.  Coordinate and work in a collegial manner with the agencyâ€™s technology team and the team at DOITT; serve as a subject matter expert on the use of electronic marketing technology and trends, cutting-edge applications, and content delivery systems, and make recommendations for changes as needed.  Manage site feedback from all internal and external sources and initiate strategies to maximize visitor usability; communicate with DOITT for backend architecture support as necessary.   Track and report on all site metrics.

job_description: As part of the Mayorâ€™s Office of Operations, HHS Accelerator and Connect are the Cityâ€™s go-to resource for harnessing digital tools and capabilities to improve the lives of low-income and vulnerable New Yorkers, with the policy, management and technical expertise to help produce better outcomes for residents. working to integrate Performance Management with all HR Talent Management functions; assisting management in conducting performance calibration sessions; managing the annual performance evaluation process and cyclical activities; job_description: The Office of Chief Medical Examiner investigates cases of persons who die within New York City from criminal violence, by accident, by suicide, suddenly when in apparent health, when unattended by a physician, in a correctional facility or in any suspicious or unusual manner or where an application is made pursuant to law for a permit to cremate a body of a person and provides for the proper disposition of unclaimed bodies.  We exist to provide answers in support of families, victims and community during time of profound need.   The core values of the OCME are to put the mission of the agency first, to be truly dedicated and to have integrity in every aspect of our professional life.  Under executive direction, with wide latitude for the exercise of independent initiative and judgment, the Deputy Chief Medical Examiner will be in charge of and responsible for confidential medico-legal investigations of violent, suspicious, sudden and unexpected deaths throughout the boroughs offices. Within the framework established by law, s/he will develop policies and translate central office policies and directives into operating procedures and methods to be used by medical examiners. Duties include but are not limited to:  â€¢  Under the executive direction of the Chief Medical Examiner, the selected candidates will serve as the Deputy Chief Medical Examiner with day-to-day responsibility for the overall operation of the Office of Chief Medical Examiner office.   â€¢  Will perform autopsies and supervise the performance of autopsies, histological and pathological examinations to determine the cause of death including collecting tissue samples for examination.  â€¢  Will be responsible for post-mortem microscopic and macroscopic, chemical, serologic and bacteriological examinations including determining the competence of forensic pathological determinations. â€¢  Will advise District Attorneys, testify as an expert before grand juries, courts and other legal authorities as an official of the Office of Chief Medical Examiner â€¢  Will supervise investigations at the scenes of crimes or violent deaths as requested by the NYPD.  â€¢  Will perform autopsies and other examinations in especially complex and unusual cases, review hospital records and/or family history and request further investigation as needed. Will meet with family members and emergency responders and other affected entities as needed to aid in the determination of the cause of death.  â€¢  Will perform case triage, assign autopsies, train, and supervise subordinate City Medical Examiners in the performance of autopsies and the completion of death certificates.   â€¢  Will participate in lectures and teaching, and will perform gross demonstrations to students.  â€¢  Will supervise the establishment of and maintenance of records and reporting systems.  â€¢  Other duties as assigned.  SPECIAL NOTE:  1.  The selected candidate will be required to provide a DNA sample by swabbing. 2.  This position has been identified as â€œessential.â€ During ALL weather and emergency events, â€œessentialâ€ positions may require 24-hour availability.
minimum_qual_requirements: A license to practice medicine valid in the State of New York; and a Diplomate of the American Board of Pathology in anatomic and forensic pathology; and four (4) years of full-time experience in forensic pathology in the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner or in a comparable agency, at least one (1) year of which must have been in a supervisory or administrative capacity; and evidence of having performed at least 500 autopsies.

job_description: The NYC Department of Homeless Services (DHS) seeks one (1) Summer Graduate Intern for the Emergency Preparedness and Operations Unit (housed within the Division of Security and Emergency Operations).  The selected candidate will be responsible for both internal agency preparedness activities, such as working on the Agency's continuity of operations plan, hazard specific planning (e.g. how the agency would respond and take care of its clients in the event of a coastal storm or pandemic) as well as citywide planning regarding emergency shelter planning for the City of New York. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university  including or supplemented by 28 semester credits in the physical or natural sciences, civil engineering, mechanical engineering, environmental engineering, chemical engineering and/or toxicology and one year of satisfactory, full-time experience  in the identification, evaluation and control of health and safety hazards; or    3. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university and two years of satisfactory full-time work experience as described in â€œ2â€ above; or    4. A combination of education and experience that is the equivalent of the course work and/or experience  described in â€œ1â€, â€œ2â€, and â€œ3â€ above. Semester credits from an accredited college or university in industrial hygiene, environmental health science, occupational health science and/or safety engineering may be substituted for experience on the basis of 7 semester credits equals 6 months of experience, up to a maximum of 28 semester credits. Semester credits from an accredited college or university  in the physical or natural sciences, civil engineering, mechanical engineering, environmental engineering, chemical engineering and/or toxicology may be substituted for experience on the basis of 7 semester credits equals 3 months of experience, up to a maximum of 28 semester credits. NDDâ€™s goal is to create and support sustainable local partner organizations that advance the small business environments of communities across the Cityâ€™s five boroughs. NDD seeks empathic, patient, and compassionate individuals with a strong desire to work at the intersection of city government and community-based organizations, proactively engaging neighborhood stakeholders throughout the planning process. partner CBDOs to analyze opportunities and challenges on their respective commercial corridors, creating a publicly-presented district needs assessment report that includes information and data about assessments, including creating metrics by which to measure short, medium, and long-term success â€¢Work with partner CBDOs to leverage the district needs assessments to access additional resources and information to develop and implement commercial revitalization projects in subsequent years  â€¢Serve as the â€˜neighborhood championâ€™ for the PMâ€™s assigned geographies, spearheading efforts with other City agencies and community stakeholders/organizations â€¢Coordinate intra-agency working groups on assigned neighborhoods and geographies, meeting frequently to move projects forward, groups â€¢Other projects, contract management responsibilities, and tasks as assigned

job_description: New York Cityâ€™s Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) seeks a dynamic candidate for an Analyst position in the Division of Strategic Planning (DSP), housed within the Office of Strategy, Research, and Communications.  DSP is responsible for shaping and implementing agency priority projects that address the most critical housing policy issues facing HPD and the City as a whole, to help meet the ambitious goals of the Housing New York plan. DSP is also responsible for carrying out projects which address and improve upon the agencyâ€™s operations, often crossing divisional lines within the agency, and coordinating with external city agencies and non-profit partners.   JOB DESCRIPTION Reporting to the Assistant Commissioner of Strategic Planning, the Analyst must be able to work independently and collaboratively with other teams across the agency, including senior staff, to identify, clarify, analyze, and resolve complex issues critical to HPDâ€™s strategic policy and operating success.  The ideal candidate will be enterprising, resourceful, organized and results-oriented. The candidate will have an ability to work with large data sets and translate findings for senior HPD staff to make efficient, effective, and equitable policy decisions.  The person who fulfills this role will apply his or her analytic and problem-solving skills in a proactive, collaborative, and strategic way. The candidate should possess strong financial analysis skills and, preferably, a thorough understanding of real estate economics.  In addition, the candidate should feel comfortable working in a small group within a large organization, setting direction while working flexibly within existing constraints and shifting priority projects.   The candidate will be expected to work directly with stakeholders at all levels of the agency. As such, teamwork, diplomacy, and consensus building are essential components of the Analystâ€™s work.  The candidate should also be able to operate independently, carry out assignments in a timely fashion, and demonstrate sound judgment in decision-making.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and two years of experience in community work or community centered activities in an area related to the duties described above; or  2. High school graduation or equivalent and six years of experience in community work or community centered activities in an area related to the duties as described above; or  3. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least one year of experience as described in ''1'' above.
preferred_skills: In addition to the above, specific qualifications and responsibilities of the Analyst include:  1-3 years professional experience working in a financial/economic analysis, program evaluation, and/or policy analysis capacity;   Strong interest in public policy, real estate economics, and/or city government is critical, as well as experience in applying strategic thinking and project management skills to the organizationâ€™s mission;  Ability to use analytic tools, such as proprietary financial models, maps, and large data sets, to understand real estate sub-markets and housing needs, and then use creative thinking to develop solutions and programs which will address those findings;    Ability to conduct financial analysis and to use and interpret financial and other quantitative data to inform housing policy, including project costs, land valuation, and financing terms  Ability to work creatively under strict deadlines in a problem-solving environment;  Ability to regularly communicate with supervisors and clients regarding project status and challenges, and synthesize complex and disparate information into presentations, memos, e-mails, and agendas;  Ability to analyze complex issue and synthesize them into accessible and compelling content and to present them effectively;  Entrepreneurial approach to problem solving and policy analysis;  Ability to meet deadlines and manage multiple projects in a timely manner;  Strong written and oral communications and presentation skills;  Strong proficiency with Microsoft Excel, PowerPoint, and Word;  Advanced degree in a relevant field is strongly preferred (e.g. Business Administration, Economics, Public Administration, Public Policy, Real Estate Finance, Urban/Regional Planning, Law, etc.).

job_description: ***Revised***    The NYC Department of Homeless Services (DHS) seeks (2) Associate Staff Analysts to serve as Program Analysts for the Regional Director Unit of the Division of Family Services. The selected candidates will oversee the social services that not-for-profit providers perform for DHS; assist in developing Requests for Proposals (RFP's); provide social services technical  assistance to the DHS Agency Chief Contracting Officers, and read/rate proposals that are submitted. In addition the Program Analysts will work with providers to establish short-term/long-term operational staffing goals; conduct operational reviews, workforce planning analyses, and routine/special site visits to ensure that all agency requirements are applicable and City, State and Federal regulations are met. They will analyze, review and approve operating budgets and financial plans, and participate in the design and implementation of performance measurement standards. They will conduct reviews of client case histories, independent living skills, exit interviews, ensure the documentation meets all agency requirements; and assist providers in designing strategies to motivate difficult clients. Additionally, the Program Analysts may represent the Agency during community meetings and/or discussions with local officials and community leaders. (1393,1389)    Candidates must be serving as a permanent Associate Staff Analyst or provide proof of filing for the Associate Staff Analyst examination in order to be considered for this position.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A masterâ€™s degree from an accredited college or university, accredited by regional, national, professional or specialized agencies recognized as accrediting bodies by the U.S. Secretary of Education and the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA) in economics, finance, accounting, business or public administration, human resources management, management science, operations research, organizational behavior, industrial psychology, statistics, personnel administration, labor relations, psychology, sociology, human resources development, political science, urban studies or a closely related field, and one year of satisfactory full-time professional experience in one or a combination of the following: working with the budget of a large public or private concern in budget administration, accounting, economic or financial administration, or fiscal or economic research; or in management or methods analysis, operations research, organizational research or program evaluation; or in personnel or public administration, recruitment, position classification, personnel relations, labor relations, employee   benefits, staff development, employment program planning/administration, labor market research, economic planning, social services program planning/evaluation, or fiscal management; or in a related area; or  2. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university, accredited by regional, national, professional or specialized agencies recognized as accrediting bodies by the U.S. Secretary of Education and the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA) and three years of satisfactory full-time professional experience in the areas described in â€œ1'' above.

job_description: Under general supervision, serves as Civil Engineer in the Engineering Review Section of the Bureau of Engineering Review and Support.  Reviews City-let bridge construction contracts drawings at various phases of design.  Reviews design calculations, Bridge Rehabilitation Project Reports, seismic reports, load ratings and life cycle cost analysis reports for compliance with City, State and Federal standards.  Coordinates with other agencies, private developers, and utility companies for projects that come within the proximity of city owned bridges.  Reviews overweight/over-dimensional truck/crane permit applications.  Performs field visits to determine conditions of bridges and retaining walls for scope preparation.  Coordinates progress meetings.  Performs other related duties.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) Four (4) years of full-time, satisfactory experience in civil engineering work; and   (2) A valid New York State Professional Engineerâ€™s License. Current New York State registration as a Professional Engineer must be maintained for the duration of your employment.    A masters degree in civil engineering from an accredited college or university, accredited by regional, national, professional or specialized agencies recognized as accrediting bodies by the U.S. Secretary of Education and by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA) may be substituted for one year of the civil engineering experience required in â€œ1'' above.  Special Note:  In addition to above qualification requirements, to be eligible for placement in Assignment Levels II and III, individuals must have at least one year within the last three years of experience as a major contributor or a project leader on a complex project requiring additional and specific expertise in the disciplines needed to design or construct the project.
preferred_skills: Ability to communicate effectively in verbal and written form.  Knowledge of AASHTO LRFD Bridge Design specifications, AASHTO Manual for Bridge Evaluation, and the NYSDOT Bridge manual is preferrred.  Knowledge of structural analysis programs STAAD, LARSA, and SAP2000 is also preferred.
additional_information: TO BE APPOINTED TO ANY CIVIL ENGINEERING POSITION IN BRIDGES, CANDIDATES MUST POSSESS ONE YEAR OF CIVIL ENGINEERING EXPERIENCE IN BRIDGE DESIGN, BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION, BRIDGE MAINTENANCE OR BRIDGE INSPECTION.

job_description: The Junior Tax Credit Analyst is responsible for allocating federal Low Income Housing Tax Credits for the financing of affordable housing. The Junior Analyst will be required to underwrite credit applications as well as in the detailed review of: lending commitments, evidence of site control, property appraisals, and other development related documents. Other responsibilities will include but will not be limited to: performing financial analyses, scoring of applications, preparing routine correspondence and legal allocation documents, collecting information and data of current and historical nature for the use in the preparation of documents and reports, maintenance of records of factual and statistical information, responding to telephone and correspondence requests for information requiring research, performing quantitative analysis and preparing reports thereon.

business_title: Health Information and Insurance Analyst, Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS)
business_title_phonetic: Health Information and Insurance Analyst, Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS)
job_description: AMENDED PROGRAM DESCRIPTION **  Salary Range:  $ 56,555.00 Hiring Rate (Flat Rate)  On-board After One Year: $62,210.00- $ 68,431.00 (Annual)   The Health Departmentâ€™s Division of Prevention and Primary Care, Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS) is responsible for the delivery of all health and mental health services in the NYC jail system.  The CHS health system includes approximately 11,000 patients at any given time and 70,000 annual admissions.  Direct services are delivered by a combination of CHS and vendor staff.  Core CHS activities include formulating and implementing all policies and procedures as well as administering quality assurance, quality improvement and morbidity and mortality processes and discharge planning.  CHS also works closely with the Bureau of Information Technology Initiatives to promote high quality health care through refinement of the jail electronic health records and its connection to various community health resources.   The responsibilities for the Health Information and Insurance Analyst will include, but not be limited to:  â€¢	Conduct quality assurance on existing and evolving health information and insurance initiatives.  â€¢	Act as a liaison between Health Information and Insurance Senior Director and Bureau of ITI, PCAP and the Division of Mental Hygiene to identify data needs and reports to support health information and insurance initiatives.  â€¢	Provide data analysis support to the Director of Medical Informatics as well CHS evaluation and research staff; specifically preparing large datasets including Medicaid claims and electronic health record data.  â€¢	Support workflow design and implementation.  â€¢	Assist with the production and publication of peer-reviewed articles.  â€¢	Develop and deliver presentations as needed on health information and insurance topics.   â€¢	Contribute to the research of  current state and federal policies and legislative efforts to assist the Senior Director identify opportunities to enhance health information and insurance initiatives in the city jails and with individuals discharged from jail.   â€¢	Other duties to support the work of the Health Information and Insurance Senior Director as needed.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1.  For Assignment Level I (only physical, biological and environmental sciences and public health) A master's degree from an accredited college or university with a specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological or environmental science or in public health.  To be appointed to Assignment Level II and above, candidates must have:  1. A doctorate degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and one year of full-time experience in a responsible supervisory, administrative or research capacity in the appropriate field of specialization; or  2. A master's degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and three years of responsible full-time research experience in the appropriate field of specialization; or  3. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least a master's degree in an appropriate field of specialization and at least two years of experience described in ''2'' above. Two years as a City Research Scientist Level I can be substituted for the experience required in ''1'' and ''2'' above.    NOTE:  Probationary Period  Appointments to this position are subject to a minimum probationary period of one year.
preferred_skills: â€¢	Strong data/statistical analysis and database management skills;   â€¢	ability to use Windows and Microsoft Office Suite as well as standard statistical software packages;   â€¢	experience using and working with electronic health records (EHRs);   â€¢	understanding of and experience with working on health information projects that develop and/or enhance public health service delivery; and  â€¢	ability to work in a jail environment.

business_title_phonetic: Research Analyst, Family and Child Health Administration
job_description: The Division of Family and Child Health (DFCH) is charged with the creation and oversight of programs, policies, services, and environments that support physical and socio-emotional health, and promote primary and reproductive health services, health equity, social justice, safety and well-being for New York City families and children. The Division is comprised of the Bureau of Maternal Infant and Reproductive Health, the Bureau of Early Intervention, the Office of School Health and DFCH Administration.  Reporting to the Divisionâ€™s Research Director, the Research Analyst will be responsible for, but not limited to, the following:  â€¢	Analyze survey, administrative and other data using SAS and SUDDAN to estimate prevalence, evaluate differences between groups, monitor trends over time and model associations.   â€¢	Use SAS, including merge statements, macros and SQL, to manipulate and clean data and create analytic data sets; develop and maintain code books and other data documentation.   â€¢	Use Arc GIS or other mapping software to display spatial associations in data.  â€¢	Contribute to the production and dissemination of reports, presentations and manuscripts. â€¢	Research, evaluate and help select survey items.   â€¢	Conduct regular reviews of the literature, and synthesize and disseminate important findings.  â€¢	Support the Research Director in the development and implementation of new research initiatives.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1.  For Assignment Level I (only physical, biological and environmental sciences and public health) A master's degree from an accredited college or university with a specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological or environmental science or in public health.  To be appointed to Assignment Level II and above, candidates must have:  1. A doctorate degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and one year of full-time experience in a responsible supervisory, administrative or research capacity in the appropriate field of specialization; or  2. A master's degree from an accredited college or university with specialization in an appropriate field of physical, biological, environmental or social science and three years of responsible full-time research experience in the appropriate field of specialization; or  3. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least a master's degree in an appropriate field of specialization and at least two years of experience described in ''2'' above. Two years as a City Research Scientist Level I can be substituted for the experience required in ''1'' and ''2'' above.    NOTE:  Probationary Period  Appointments to this position are subject to a minimum probationary period of one year.
preferred_skills: â€¢	Advanced degree in epidemiology or another quantitative social science  â€¢	Experience in managing and analyzing large survey and administrative datasets using data management and statistical software (e.g., SAS, SUDAAN, R, SQL, Stata); experience with MACRO programming and GIS software a plus  â€¢	Ability to design analyses, synthesize results, and present findings succinctly. â€¢	Ability to prioritize and handle multiple tasks  â€¢	Strong written and oral communication skills  â€¢	Desire to become a content expert in the field of family and child health.

job_description: The NYC Department of Buildings is responsible for ensuring the safe and lawful use of buildings and properties by enforcing the NYC Construction Codes, Energy Code and Zoning Resolution. We facilitate compliant development with integrity, efficiency and professionalism. We are committed to becoming a premier municipal building organization, dedicated to enhancing the quality of life for all New Yorkers and making our city safer. We are committed to improving our performance and developing procedures that are streamlined, understandable and transparent.     Reporting to the Director of Engineering, Division of Technical Affairs and Code Development, the Code Development Architect will work on various technical subject matters. The selected candidate will:    Perform complex research regarding construction codes, zoning resolution and related laws and rules, often under tight deadlines  Answer questions from the public regarding construction codes, zoning resolution and related laws and rules  Draft proposed construction code and rule revisions  Participate in the triennial construction code revision process  Assist with the adoption of an existing building code  Draft Buildings Bulletins that provide the public with interpretations and clarifications on complex issues relating to the construction codes, zoning resolution and related laws and rules  Prepare presentation materials such as powerpoint slides and informational sketches in AutoCAD and other drawing programs, for a variety of audiences including agency staff, technically proficient industry representatives, City Council members and staff and the general public   Support and further the  Agencyâ€™s commitment to improving operations and implementation of technology based solutions  Assist the Director of Engineering and other level personnel on projects as required
minimum_qual_requirements: A  valid New York State Registration as an Architect is required. In addition, candidates must have six ( 6 ) years of full-time paid experience in architectural work, at least two (2) years of which shall have been as an administrative architect.
preferred_skills: Ability to work independently.  Ability to write complex technical issues in a clear and concise manner; Please submit writing sample with resume.  Demonstrated excellent communication, organization and writing skills.  Demonstrated ability/potential to work effectively with and motivate project teams in both leading and supporting roles.      Experience managing multiple projects and delivering results on time.  Knowledge of the New York City Construction Codes and Zoning Resolution.  Candidates with knowledge and experience with the NYS Multiple Dwelling Law given special consideration.  Candidates with knowledge and experience with the design requirement of means of egress systems given special consideration.

Performing fact finding interviews of subjects and witnesses.  Performing fieldwork, consisting of surveillance, quality assurance checks, and various undercover operations.  Researching public records.  Reviewing voluminous and complicated facts to ascertain their validity.  Utilizing various database and web based programs to verify and gather information.   Writing lengthy, narrative reports.  Analyzing and Interpreting rules, regulations, codes and policies.  Testifying at administrative hearings and criminal trials.   Performing background investigations for employees, contractors and registrants.  Testifying in administrative and criminal courts.  Working on special projects and tasks as assigned by the Executive Director of IAD.  Must be willing to work flexible hours

job_description: The Junior Tax Credit Analyst is responsible for allocating federal Low Income Housing Tax Credits for the financing of affordable housing. The Junior Analyst will be required to underwrite credit applications as well as in the detailed review of lending commitments, evidence of site control, property appraisals, and other development related documents. Other responsibilities will include but will not be limited to: performing financial analyses, scoring of applications, preparing routine correspondence and legal allocation documents, collecting information and data of current and historical nature for the use in the preparation of documents and reports, maintenance of records of factual and statistical information, responding to telephone and correspondence requests for information requiring research, performing quantitative analysis and preparing reports thereon.

business_title: Director of External Content & Social Media
business_title_phonetic: Director of External Content & Social Media
job_description: The NYC Department of Homeless Services seeks an Administrative Public Information Specialist M1 to serve as the Director of External Content & Social Media. The Director will manage the Agency's web content and manage all new media campaigns related to the agency such as HOPE, Prevention as well as operational plan branding. The Director will manage new media outlets to push out interesting and positive stories, generate context on issues related to homelessness and help with rapid response campaigning. The Director will also manage the implementation of our monthly newsletters, ad campaigns and assist with strategizing and implementation of public awareness campaigns related to the Agencies work to reduce homelessness and improve lives. S/he will generate, create and implement all new media content which includes emails from the Office of the Commissioner and Communications and external outlets; develop and edit content for internal and external publications for the Agency including brochures and other print materials that promote the DHS message; and create and implement design and graphic changes to brochures and print materials as well as coordinate, develops, write and edit all internal and external content, including program updates and articles promoting DHS achievements, on the Agency's intranet and public website. The Director will maintain DHS social media accounts, including Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and other sites; work to revise outdated text on the Agency website and intranet, including special events and providers profile section; and manage biweekly new media and website design with programing staff, supervise photography for special events; upload, edit, and organize images for use on the website, intranet, and print materials; oversee and consult on production for informational videos; serve as a liaison between DHS and DOITT, make frequent website updates, including articles and photos, job postings, notices of public hearings, and other essential (and time-sensitive) Agency issues; and work with 311 to update Agency's 311 script, related to agency programs, services and information; and work with 311 to develop and maintain list of Frequently Asked Questions for use on website.  The selected candidate will help with general operation of the Office of Communications and in all circumstances, work closely with Deputy Commissioner, Assistant Commissioner, and staff to promote Agency messaging and mission, however and whenever possible.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A Baccalaureate degree from an accredited college with 24 credits in English, journalism or public relations, plus five (5) years of full-time paid experience in public relations, journalism or advertising, including two (2) years in an administrative, supervisory or consultative capacity; or  2. A combination of education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' above. Graduate study in English, journalism, or public relations may be substituted for up to one year of required experience. However, all candidates must have at least two (2) years of administrative, supervisory, or consultative experience in public relations, journalism or advertising.

job_description: The NYC Department of Homeless Services (DHS) seeks a candidate to serve as the Director of the Linden Avenue Men's Shelter within the Adult Services Division. S/he will ensure the health, safety and welfare of DHS clients and staff on-site, monitor the physical plant to ensure an acceptable level of cleanliness and will ensure full compliance with all applicable legal mandates, agency standards and regulatory requirements, such as NYC Building Department codes, NYC Fire Department regulations, NYS Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance (OTDA) rules governing homeless shelter, NYS Public Employee Safety and Health (PESH) regulations, and the Callahan Consent Decree governing clients' shelter rights.     S/he will ensure the effective management of program capacity; oversee the timely provision of bed assignments for new and returning clients and will work closely with Vacancy Control to coordinate transports and report shelter census and bed availability figures. S/he will oversee the provisions of social services and will provide direction and support to ensure programmatic goals and objectives are achieved, clients' social service needs are met and independent living plans are developed, monitored and executed. S/e will also participate in weekly case conferences with social services staff to address and resolve deficiencies, and will manage external relationships with community groups and the local Community Board to address community concerns and promote good relations.    In addition, the selected candidate will oversee the administrative functions of the facility to ensure that staff adhere to City and Agency policies and procedures with respect to time and leave regulations, absence control provisions, overtime allocations and control plans. S/he will also foster compliance with the Agency Code of Conduct and enforce any other applicable city, state and federal directives.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university and four years of progressively responsible experience, including one year at the administrative or managerial level in a large governmental agency, business firm, civic or community organization operating in the area of social services; or  2. Education and/or experience equivalent to ''1'' above. However, all candidates must have a baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and the one year of experience at the administrative or management level as described in ''1'' above.
preferred_skills: Extensive Social Services background and strong writing, communications and organizational skills are required. Fire Safety Coordinator Training is a plus.

job_description: The NYC Department of Homeless Services (DHS) seeks a qualified individual to serve as an Administrative Staff Analyst NM in the Permanency Planning unit within the Family Services Division. The selected candidate will process Enhanced One Shot Deals (EOSD), as well as applications for NYCHA, LINC, and HPD Section 8. The Client Resources Analyst will be responsible for reviewing application packets for completeness of required documents, communicating with providers about missing documentation, scheduling lease signings, and troubleshooting issues as they arise. The Client Resources Analyst will also be required to run queries of the agency's information systems. S/he will assist the division in the production of reports to monitor the progress of provider agencies in meeting exit targets.  This position is labor intensive and requires an organized individual who can work well with others and handle a high intensity and fast-paced environment.    Candidates must be serving as a permanent Administrative Staff Analyst or provide proof of filing for the Administrative Staff Analyst examination in order to be considered for this position.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A master's degree from an accredited college in economics, finance, accounting, business or public administration, human resources management, management science, operations research, organizational behavior, industrial psychology, statistics, personnel administration, labor relations, psychology, sociology, human resources development, political science, urban studies or a closely related field, and two years of satisfactory full-time professional experience in one or a combination of the following: working with the budget of a large public or private concern in budget administration, accounting, economic or financial administration, or fiscal or economic research; in management or methods analysis, operations research, organizational research or program evaluation; in personnel or public administration, recruitment, position classification, personnel relations, employee benefits, staff development, employment program planning/administration, labor market research, economic planning, social services program planning/evaluation, or fiscal management; or in a related area. 18 months of this experience must have been in an executive, managerial, administrative or supervisory capacity. Supervision must have included supervising staff performing professional work in the areas described above; or  2. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and four years of professional experience in the areas described in ''1'' above, including the 18 months of executive, managerial, administrative or supervisory experience, as described in ''1'' above.
preferred_skills: Candidates must have a strong background in data and policy analysis, research methodology, program evaluation, as well as a comfort using large data sets. They must possess experience with SPSS, STATA, or SAS. Knowledge of query/report generation software such as SQL or PLSQL preferred. Excellent written and verbal communication skills are also required. MPA or masters' degree in a social policy related field is a plus. An assessment of SPSS skills will be conducted prior to selection.

business_title: Sr Advisor to the Deputy Commissioner of Fiscal & Procurement Operations
business_title_phonetic: Sr Advisor to the Deputy Commissioner of Fiscal & Procurement Operations
job_description: The Department of Homeless Services (DHS) is a multi-faceted NYC agency whose mission is to overcome homelessness in New York City. With our partners our goal is to prevent homelessness when possible; to provide temporary, emergency shelter when needed; and to help Individuals and families transition rapidly into permanent housing. We do this through providing coordinated, compassionate, high â€“quality services, and support.     DHS seeks an exceptional candidate for the position of Senior Advisor in the Fiscal, Procurement and Audit Division.   The selected candidate will report to the Deputy Commissioner and will be responsible for working with and supporting the four divisions within Fiscal, Procurement and Audit Services.     The Senior Advisor will assist in the divisions overall responsibility of ensuring that financial and contractual obligations for the Agency are met in response to City, State and Federal guidelines.   Fiscal, Procurement and Audit Services consists of four key areas:  â€¢Agency Chief Contracting Office  â€¢Budget, Revenue and Claiming   â€¢Finance/Payments   â€¢Audit Services/Invoice Verification    The Senior Advisor will work closely with the Deputy Commissioner and Assistant Commissioners to support the planning, implementation and monitoring of all aspects of capacity development within the Agency. Project manage the automation of systems to track all active provider contracts and modify current system process for tracking all contractual actions from inception to registration.  The Special Advisor may represent the Division at meetings with providers and other DHS stakeholders.  The Senior Advisor will serve as the lead in researching ways of enhancing local, State and federal funding and to research the reprogramming of existing funding sources towards establishing mixed shelter/permanent housing models.  The Senior Advisor will respond to, evaluate and provide comprehensive analysis of requests from non-profit providers and other government entities. The Senior Advisor will possess superior analytic capacity, including the ability to creatively synthesize ideas, problem solve and receive and use input/feedback from multiple sources and make complex, informed decisions.    Candidates must be serving as a permanent Administrative Staff Analyst or provide proof of filing for the Administrative Staff Analyst examination in order to be considered for this position.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. job_description: The Bureau of Alcohol and Drug Use Prevention, Care and Treatment (BADUPCT) works to reduce morbidity and mortality related to alcohol and substance use among New Yorkers. BADUPCT develops, implements and evaluates interventions and prevention strategies through: Contracting of treatment, recovery and support services; Policy analysis and development; Epidemiology and surveillance; Dissemination of treatment and management guidelines; Harm reduction initiatives; Public and provider outreach and education and; Community involvement and interagency collaboration.    The Clinical Systems Integration Coordinator will coordinate implementation and evaluation of activities related to the integration of drug and alcohol public health initiatives into primary care and hospital-based settings. Examples of initiatives include developing infrastructure to increase access to treatment for opioid addiction (i.e., buprenorphine) in general practice; partnering with health centers and hospitals to promote DOHMH opioid analgesic guidelines for safe and judicious prescribing; and supporting increased use of Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) in clinical practice. The work will encompass a variety of general domains in public health, including project management, policy, community outreach (e.g., with health care providers), and evaluation.     Under direction from the supervisor, the Clinical Systems Integration Coordinator will have wide latitude for the exercise of independent judgment and initiative to perform the following tasks:      DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:    --  Design and execute integration activities/research, Manage (e.g., make and record observations) on the progress of integration activities/research.    -- Evaluate integration activities/research, Analyze and interpret data related to integration activities/research.    -- Liaise/communicate regularly with health care providers, Identify community-based champions for specific initiatives.    -- Organize and conduct trainings for health care providers and their staff, Identify best practices, innovation, and opportunities to develop and improve integration activities.    -- Assist in policy development to promote integration activities, Stay up-to-date on relevant drug and alcohol-related research, policy, and news.    -- Alert team to noteworthy updates, Create and deliver power point presentations to  internal staff and external partners.    -- Maintain records and prepare reports, Write concise summaries of activities and findings,  Budgeting.    -- Track grant deliverables and prepare reports.    -- Work closely and coordinate with other units in BADUPCT.    -- Assist in coordination of integration activities/research efforts of the agency with other integration activities/research efforts.    -- Other duties as assigned.

Ability to multi-task in a fast-paced, high volume environment. Proficiency in Excel, Access, Word, PowerPoint, and Visio.
to_apply: Apply online with a cover letter to https://a127-jobs.nyc.gov/.  In the Job ID search bar, enter: job ID number #148869.      We appreciate the interest and thank all applicants who apply, but only those candidates under consideration will be contacted.
residency_requirement: New York City residency is generally required within 90 days of appointment. However, City Employees in certain titles who have worked for the City for 2 continuous years may also be eligible to reside in Nassau, Suffolk, Putnam, Westchester, Rockland, or Orange County. To determine if the residency requirement applies to you, please discuss with the agency representative at the time of interview.
